title: Conductors - charged glass rod  metal spheres

content.question: Two metal spheres are connected by a copper wire and are initially uncharged. A positively charged glass rod is then brought near Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and held in place without touching Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. Which of the following correctly describes the charge and electric potential of the two spheres while the glass rod is held in place?

choices.label: Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is negatively charged, Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is positively charged, and the potential of Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is less than the potential of Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.

Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is negatively charged, Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is positively charged, and the potential of Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is equal to the potential of Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.

Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> are both negatively charged, and the potential of Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is equal to the potential of Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.

Neither Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> nor Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> has a net charge and the potential of Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is greater than the potential of Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.

content.answer: Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is negatively charged, Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is positively charged, and the potential of Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is equal to the potential of Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.
